results:
Based on the search results, I can provide comprehensive information about Polish adaptations, translations, and editions of "Alice in Wonderland" (Alicja w Krainie Czarów):

## Polish Translations (Polskie tłumaczenia)

The first Polish translation was by Adela S. in 1910, published by Wydawnictwo M. Arcta in Warsaw. The title page showed "Przygody Alinki w Krainie Cudów" while the cover read "Przygody Alinki w Krainie Czarów". The full surname of the translator is unknown.

Maria Morawska's translation from 1927 was commissioned by Gebethner and Wolff, titled "Ala w krainie czarów". It was published three times before the war, then in 1947 and finally in 1997.

Antoni Marianowicz created a translation in 1955. This version is directed more towards children. The translator replaces original poems with adapted Polish ones, like "Pan Kotek był chory".

In 1965, Maciej Słomczyński created the first translation faithful to the original, directed at older readers.

Jolanta Kozak's 1999 translation uniquely preserved the title structure, translating "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland" as "Przygody Alicji w Krainie Czarów".

Bogumiła Kaniewska created a translation in 2010, faithful to the original, containing both parts.

As of 2015, there were already twelve Polish translations of the book.

## Theatre Adaptations (Adaptacje teatralne)

The Nowy Teatr im. Witkacego in Słupsk staged a musical version directed by Wojciech Kościelniak, based on his own translation of Lewis Carroll's "Alice in Wonderland". The premiere was on March 19, 2023.

The Teatr Narodowy presented "Alicji Kraina Czarów," a musical performance based on Lewis Carroll's famous novels, directed by Sławomir Narloch, with premiere on March 4, 2023.

Teatr Muzyczny Roma staged a musical performance directed by Cezary Domagała with premiere on May 23, 2015.

Teatr Śląski im. St. Wyspiańskiego in Katowice also staged "Alicja w Krainie Czarów," noting it as possibly the only case in history where one story contains two: for children and for adults.

## Film Adaptations (Adaptacje filmowe)

A 1951 Disney animated adaptation of Lewis Carroll's book tells the story of a girl who followed the White Rabbit, fell into his hole and found herself in a world full of fairy-tale creatures.

The 2010 Tim Burton film had its Polish premiere on March 5, 2010. Polish dubbing featured actors including Cezary Pazura, Małgorzata Kożuchowska, Katarzyna Figura, Bartłomiej Topa, Jan Peszek, and Małgorzata Braunek.

Although nine different Polish translations of the book were available at the time of the film's premiere, Jan Jakub Wecsile, responsible for the Polish dialogues, didn't base them on any existing translation, creating his own versions of Carroll's invented names. For example, "vorpal sword" became "turpi koncerz" and "Jabberwocky" became "Żaberzwłok".

## Publishing History (Historia wydawnicza)

The term "Kraina Czarów" (Wonderland) appears in the title of ten translations, while in the eleventh (by Grzegorz Wasowski) the magical element is preserved but the location is changed to "Czarytorium".

The translations have been illustrated by various Polish artists over the years, and classic John Tenniel illustrations most often appear with Maria Morawska's translation from 1927.
